POST OFFICE AND TELEGRAPH (HONEY) BILL, 1931.Memorandum by the Postmaster General.Capital for development of the Postal, Telegraph and Telephone systems is provided by advances made by the National Debt Commissioners and repaid to them by means of annuities charged on the Post Office Vote. The capital expenditure authorised by the various Acts amounts to 145,021,083; the outstanding balance, i.e., amounts borrowed, les3 repayments, will be about 89,600,000 at the 31st March, 1931.The last Act was passed in 1928 and authorised the issue of capital to the extent of 27,500,000. This sum will, it is estimated, be exhausted by about the end of May 1931. .The Bill will authorise the issue of 32,000,000 of which it is estimated that 29,200,000 will be required for the Telephone service and 2,800,000 for the Postal and Telegraph services. It is anticipated that this sum, when added to the unexpended balance of 2,000,000 available as at 31 March, 1931 from the previous Act, will meet the capital requirements to the 31st March, 1934. The actual expenditure and the works to be carried out in each year are subject to the approval of the Treasury.C. R. ATTLEE.GENERAL POST OFFICE. 24 March, 1931.
